title: Lori Loughlin is 'considering taking a plea deal in after Felicity Huffman's light sentencing'
text:
Lori Loughlin is reportedly seeking to take a plea deal for her role in the college admissions scandal after seeing Felicity Huffman's lenient sentence of 14 days in a cushy prison.

Sources tell TMZ that Loughlin and her husband Mossimo Giannulli are considering taking the plea that they initially rejected before being hit with additional charges that could see them facing 40 years in jail if convicted.

Sources add that the U.S. attorney is open to discussion with them due to concern about how it would look if the Fuller House actress was tried, convicted and then given a short sentence.

Huffman was given just 14 days behind bars - which she is currently serving - after it was determined that no one suffered a substantial loss after she hired someone to change her daughter's SAT answers.

And now Loughlin believes that she has an even better case that her actions did not affect anyone else, despite her and her husband allegedly paying $500,000 to get both of their daughters into USC.

Lori Loughlin and her husband Mossimo Giuannulli are reportedly seeking to take a plea deal for her role in the college admissions scandal

Felicity Huffman began her 14-day prison term last week at a cushy jail known as 'Club Fed'

Prosecutors in the college admissions scandal claim that Loughlin, 55, paid a $500,000 bribe for her daughters, Olivia Jade, 20, and Isabella Giannulli, 21, to be accepted to the university.

They initially rejected the plea deal that Huffman and other parents in the scheme took, but then they were hit with additional charged of money laundering and conspiracy that could see them facing 40 years behind bars.

On Monday it was revealed Loughlin's daughters are no longer enrolled at the University of Southern California.

The university registrar has revealed that the sisters aren't enrolled at the school anymore, according to USA Today.

They were not able to provide any other information because of student privacy

They stand accused of making it look as though their daughters were crew recruits even though neither of them took part in the sport.

And they even got the girls to pose for pictures on rowing machines, which they sent to the university alongside fake athletic profiles.

Prosecutors in the college admissions scandal claim that Loughlin, 55, paid a $500,000 bribe for her daughters, Olivia Jade, 20, and Isabella Giannulli, 21, (pictured) to be accepted to the university

Loughlin (pictured with her daughters) and her fashion-designer husband, Mossimo Giannulli, 56, have pleaded not guilty and their trials are due to begin next year.

Huffman, 56, is currently serving her sentence after being found guilty of paying admissions consultant Rick Singer $15,000 to fake the answers for her now 19-year-old daughter, Sophia.

Huffman still has 250 hours of community service to complete and must stay in prison for the next nine days.

Loughlin is planning on asking the ex-Desperate Housewife about her stay in prison in case she has to serve time.

'She’s definitely hoping that Felicity’s time in prison will go easy for her, because that will be a positive sign that, if Lori has to serve time, that she’ll be able to weather it as well,' a source told People.

'She wants to debrief Felicity after jail to find out what it was like and what her advice would be.'
description: Lori Loughlin and her husband Mossimo Giuannulli are reportedly seeking to take a plea deal for her role in the college admissions scandal.
